children.value: Start by installing a Kubernetes cluster. This can be done on one of the hyperscalers (
), cloud providers (Digital Ocean, Scaleway, etc) or on-premise in your own private network.
TODO write tutorial or create link to tutorial.

Before installing some configuration needs to happen. First thing we need to do is to configure RBAC, we need to do this to query specific endpoints from the Kubernetes API. By default
these endpoints are blocked.

kind: ClusterRole
apiVersion: rbac.authorization.k8s.io/v1
metadata:
  name: pods-list
rules:
- apiGroups: ["", "apps"]
  resources: ["pods", "pods/log", "deployments", "services", "endpoints", "nodes"]
  verbs: ["get", "list", "create", "delete"]
---
kind: ClusterRoleBinding
apiVersion: rbac.authorization.k8s.io/v1
metadata:
  name: pods-list
subjects:
- kind: ServiceAccount
  name: default
  namespace: default
roleRef:
  kind: ClusterRole
  name: pods-list
  apiGroup: rbac.authorization.k8s.io
is a package manager for Kubernetes, it helps you setting up solutions more easily. Instead of writing yaml files yourself, you use so called
(libraries), that you can reuse and configure with configuration files.
Use one of the preferred OS package managers to install the Helm client:

brew install helm

choco install kubernetes-helm

scoop install helm

gofish install helm
When you've installed the Helm client, we need to use it to initiate helm (Tiller) into your cluster. Tiller is what they call the server component of Helm.

kubectl create serviceaccount tiller --namespace kube-system
kubectl create -f ./tiller-clusterrolebinding.yaml
helm init --service-account tiller

kind: ClusterRoleBinding
apiVersion: rbac.authorization.k8s.io/v1beta1
metadata:
  name: tiller-clusterrolebinding
subjects:
- kind: ServiceAccount
  name: tiller
  namespace: kube-system
roleRef:
  kind: ClusterRole
  name: cluster-admin
  apiGroup: ""
is a reverse proxy and load balancer which allows you to expose your Kubernetes deployments more easily. Kerberos uses Traefik to expose it's APIs more easily.

dashboard:
  enabled: true
  domain: your.domain.com
  serviceType: NodePort
rbac:
    enabled: true

Kerberos Enterprise generates configurations for every surveillance camera that you want to have monitored. These configuration files
are stored centrally in a MongoDB database.
